title: Graphical Analysis POI Avg Rate of Change

content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. The graph of the differentiable function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> with domain <math alttext="negative 5.5 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 3.5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5.5</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>3.5</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown in the figure above. The areas of the regions bounded by the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis and the graph of <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> on the intervals <math alttext="open bracket, negative 5 comma 0, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="open bracket, 0 comma 2, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="open bracket, 2 comma 3, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are <math alttext="57" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>57</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="12" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, respectively. The graph of <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has horizontal tangents at <math alttext="x equals negative 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="x equals negative 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="x equals 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Let <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the function defined by <math alttext="g of x equals, the integral from 2 to x, of, f of t, d t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msubsup><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="negative 5.5 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 3.5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5.5</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>3.5</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Find the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-coordinate of each critical point of <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> on the interval <math alttext="negative 5.5 is less than x, is less than 3.5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5.5</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>3.5</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. The graph of the differentiable function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> with domain <math alttext="negative 5.5 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 3.5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5.5</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>3.5</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown in the figure above. The areas of the regions bounded by the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis and the graph of <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> on the intervals <math alttext="open bracket, negative 5 comma 0, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="open bracket, 0 comma 2, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="open bracket, 2 comma 3, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are <math alttext="57" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>57</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="12" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, respectively. The graph of <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has horizontal tangents at <math alttext="x equals negative 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="x equals negative 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="x equals 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Let <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the function defined by <math alttext="g of x equals, the integral from 2 to x, of, f of t, d t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msubsup><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="negative 5.5 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 3.5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5.5</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>3.5</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Find the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-coordinate of each critical point of <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> on the interval <math alttext="negative 5.5 is less than x, is less than 3.5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5.5</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>3.5</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) Classify each critical point from part (a) as the location of a relative minimum, a relative maximum, or neither for <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Justify each of your answers.

(c) Find the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-coordinate of each point of inflection for the graph of <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> on the interval <math alttext="negative 5.5 is less than x, is less than 3.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5.5</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>3.5</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Justify your answer.
(d) Find the value of <math alttext="g of 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(e) Find the value of <math alttext="g of negative 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(f) Must there exist a value of <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, for <math alttext="negative 5 less than k, less than 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mo><</mo><mi>k</mi><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, such that <math alttext="g prime of k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is equal to the average rate of change of <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> over the interval <math alttext="negative 5 is less than or equal to x, is less than or equal to 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Justify your answer.

(g) Find <math alttext="the limit as x approaches 3, of, the fraction with numerator 5 times g of x, and denominator 2 x, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></munder><mfrac><mrow><mn>5</mn><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(h) The function <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is defined by <math alttext="r of x equals, x squared times g of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>⋅</mo><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. It is known that <math alttext="f of 3 equals negative 12" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Find <math alttext="r prime of 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

topic.text: 1.5: Determining Limits Using Algebraic Properties of Limits

skill.text: Skill 1.C: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the classification of a given expression (e.g., Use the chain rule to find the derivative of a composite function).
